crypto.name: Fiats and Shamirs Sign Forge
crypto.desc: Fiat and Shamir run the best sign shop in town! Come and buy forged, non-interactive signs! If you're extra nice, you might even get a flag!

crypto.name: Julius Caesar
crypto.desc: To prevent frequency analysis that works on regular substitution ciphers, I change the key at regular intervals. Surely it must be secure then?

forensic.name: Event
forensic.desc:
I accidentally got a malicious program among my 1000 other programs I have numbered in a folder on my desktop (isn't that how you should organize them?), and instead of trying to find the malicious program, I thought I'd just start them all and look in the system logs to see which program was behaving strangely. That might not have been a good idea, especially since I don't know how to search the logs... Can you help?

The flag is the program name (<numbers>.exe), without path, surrounded by cratectf{}. For example cratectf{1.exe}. .

forensic.name: Forward
forensic.desc:
The flag is somewhere in the server's shared files, but how can we log in to it? All we have are a couple of files from someone who seems to be called Sam(?), could they be of any use?

Port 445 may be blocked by some ISPs. If that doesn't work, try port 21562 instead. Depending on the tools you are using, you may need to do some iptables redirection to get them to accept the new port.

forensic.name: Short routes
forensic.desc:
We've captured some traffic between two routers exchanging information with each other. They seem to be authenticating with some kind of key, can you figure out which one?

The flag is the key in plaintext surrounded by cratectf{}.

misc.name: Deserialization
misc.desc: This flag came from a serial port and was intercepted with an oscilloscope. The format is said to be "UART 8N1 9600 baud" if that's of any use.

misc.name: Echo Service
misc.desc: An incredible echo service that, to save some time , caches validation results.

misc.name: Out of Sight
misc.desc: Come and be envious of the beautiful graphics! The given program should work on both X11 and Wayland. On Windows it can be run in WSL 2.

misc.name: SecretKey
misc.desc: It's high time to enter the password and gain access to the mysterious resource!

pwn.name: Armsdealer
pwn.desc: 2 Arms? No, 32 Arms! Use these, and magical things will happen.

pwn.name: Can you really change
pwn.desc:
heating
Reading 256 bytes into an 8 byte buffer is fine, right? The compiler should complain if the code is vulnerable, right? In and of itself, this program has always had to be compiled with warnings turned off...

The task can be solved in a browser-based terminal via this link, or by talking directly to the service via the command below.

pwn.name: ClosedBSD
pwn.desc:
I have pledged allegiance to the C coroutine!

To get the challenge working locally, download the tar.gz file associated with the challenge, as well as the following disk image: disk.qcow2.gz

pwn.name: Date service
pwn.desc: Use this service to find out today's date in any format!

pwn.name: Heapie 2
pwn.desc: New memory allocator in Zig, new Heapie task.

pwn.name: Sandbox
pwn.desc:
Upload a program and we'll run it! However, it may not do anything more than allocate memory, write and read, so you won't have access to any flags!

Since the sandbox is quite restrictive, there is an example of how to create programs that the sandbox approves in example.c, sdk.c& sdk.h.

rev.name: Denial Of Service
rev.desc: Inefficient algorithms on old systems can cause them to hang.

rev.name: Eventually a Flag
rev.desc: Do you have the patience to wait a number of years for the flag to be printed?

rev.name: WASabiMacken
rev.desc: On your usual morning visit to the place in town with the best wasabi, you discover to your horror that they have closed! The door is locked, but the wasabi withdrawal is pounding in your head. You run wasmtime ./wasabimacken.wasm to try to open the door.

web.name: Articular
web.desc: A new web service for writing articles that will soon rival Wikipedia, Medium, DiVA, ACM DL and many more!
